message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Toward verified artificial intelligence
Paper Abstract: Making AI more trustworthy with a formal methods-based approach to AI system verification and validation.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Verification and validation"

Links: [{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Software verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Verification and validation of computer simulation models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation_of_computer_simulation_models"},{"title":"Informal methods of validation and verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Informal_methods_of_validation_and_verification"},{"title":"Katherine Johnson Independent Verification and Validation Facility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katherine_Johnson_Independent_Verification_and_Validation_Facility"},{"title":"Validation and verification (medical devices) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Validation_and_verification_(medical_devices)"},{"title":"Talk:Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Verification_and_Validation"},{"title":"Data validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_validation"},{"title":"Process validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Process_validation"},{"title":"Telephone number verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telephone_number_verification"}]

## Verification and Validation

Based on the search results, here's an overview of verification and validation:

### Core Definitions

Verification is the evaluation of whether or not a product, service, or system complies with a regulation, requirement, specification, or imposed condition, and is often an internal process.(no content)Validation is intended to ensure a product, service, or system results in a product, service, or system that meets the operational needs of the user.

### Key Distinction

Validation can be expressed by the query "Are you building the right thing?" and verification by "Are you building it right?"(no content)"Building the right thing" refers back to the user's needs, while "building it right" checks that the specifications are correctly implemented by the system.

### In Software Development

In software project management, software testing, and software engineering, verification and validation is the process of checking that a software system meets specifications and requirements so that it fulfills its intended purpose.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about software verification:

## Definition and Overview

Software verification is a discipline of software engineering, programming languages, and theory of computation whose goal is to assure that software satisfies the expected requirements.

## Verification vs. Validation

Software verification asks the question "Are we building the product right?"; that is, does the software conform to its specifications? Software validation asks the question "Are we building the right product?"; that is, does the software do what the user really requires?

## Types of Verification

Software verification can be performed in two main ways:

1. **Static Verification**: Static verification is the process of checking that software meets requirements by inspecting the code before it runs.

2. **Dynamic Verification**: Dynamic verification is performed during the execution of software, and dynamically checks its behavior; it is commonly known as the Test phase.

## Formal Verification

Formal verification is the use of software tools to prove properties of a formal specification, or to prove that a formal model of a system implementation satisfies its specification.(no content)Prominent examples of verified software systems include the CompCert verified C compiler and the seL4 high-assurance operating system kernel. The verification of these systems is done by ensuring the existence of a formal proof of a mathematical model of the system.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about formal methods:

## Definition

In computer science, formal methods are mathematically rigorous techniques for the specification, development, analysis, and verification of software and hardware systems.

## Purpose and Motivation

The use of formal methods for software and hardware design is motivated by the expectation that, as in other engineering disciplines, performing appropriate mathematical analysis can contribute to the reliability and robustness of a design.

## Theoretical Foundations

Formal methods employ a variety of theoretical computer science fundamentals, including logic calculi, formal languages, automata theory, control theory, program semantics, type systems, and type theory.

## Applications in Development

Formal methods can be applied at various points through the development process. Formal methods may be used to give a formal description of the system to be developed, at whatever level of detail desired. Further formal methods may depend on this specification to synthesize a program or to verify the correctness of a system.

## Real-World Applications

Formal methods are applied in different areas of hardware and software, including routers, Ethernet switches, routing protocols, security applications, and operating system microkernels such as seL4. Additionally, IBM used ACL2, a theorem prover, in the AMD x86 processor development process. Intel uses such methods to verify its hardware and firmware.

## Artificial Intelligence Overview

I've performed a web search on artificial intelligence. Here are some key findings:

### Definition and Goals

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.(no content)The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

### History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

### Types of AI

Artificial general intelligence (AGI)—sometimes called human‑level intelligence AI—is a type of artificial intelligence that would match or surpass human capabilities across virtually all cognitive tasks. In contrast, weak AI (or narrow AI) can solve one specific problem but lacks general cognitive abilities.

### Applications

Artificial intelligence has been used in applications throughout industry and academia. These include areas like architecture, contact centers, writing tasks, media analysis, video surveillance, music composition, and financial reporting.

### Recent Developments

Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.

## Artificial Intelligence Overview

I've performed a web search on artificial intelligence. Here are some key findings:

### Definition and Goals

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.(no content)The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

### History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

### Types of AI

Artificial general intelligence (AGI)—sometimes called human‑level intelligence AI—is a type of artificial intelligence that would match or surpass human capabilities across virtually all cognitive tasks. In contrast, weak AI (or narrow AI) can solve one specific problem but lacks general cognitive abilities.

### Applications

Artificial intelligence has been used in applications throughout industry and academia. These include areas like architecture, contact centers, writing tasks, media analysis, video surveillance, music composition, and financial reporting.

### Recent Developments

Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Trust (social science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_(social_science)"},{"title":"Trust metric - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_metric"},{"title":"Trustworthy AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trustworthy_AI"},{"title":"Trustworthy Software Foundation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trustworthy_Software_Foundation"},{"title":"Chain of trust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chain_of_trust"},{"title":"Trustworthy computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trustworthy_computing"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Wikipedia Signpost/2022-09-30/Recent research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedia_Signpost/2022-09-30/Recent_research"},{"title":"Trusted system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trusted_system"},{"title":"Three Fundamental Bonds and Five Constant Virtues - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_Constants"},{"title":"Trust and safety - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_and_safety"}]

Here are the search results for **Trustworthiness**:

## Definition and Core Concept

Trustworthiness refers to the characteristics or behaviors of one person that inspire positive expectations in another person. In a broader philosophical sense, trustworthiness or faithfulness is understood as commitment to reality in a consistent and reliable way.

## Social and Personal Context

Trust propensity is the tendency to make oneself vulnerable to others in general, and research suggests that this general tendency can change over time in response to key life events.(no content)People are disposed to trust and to judge the trustworthiness of other people or groups—for instance, in developing relationships with potential mentors.

## Economic Dimensions

Theoretical economical modelling demonstrates that the optimum level of trust that a rational economic agent should exhibit in transactions is equal to the trustworthiness of the other party, a level that leads to an efficient market. Trusting less leads to losing economic opportunities, while trusting more leads to unnecessary vulnerabilities and potential exploitation.

## Digital and Technological Applications

Trustworthy AI refers to artificial intelligence systems that are designed to have transparent reasoning, are explainable, accountable, robust, fair and honest, respectful of data privacy, and steerable or alignable with human goals.(no content)The term trustworthy computing has been applied to computing systems that are inherently secure, available, and reliable.
